Chapter 5 of the Sutra of the Bodhisattva King of High Virtue of Universal Illumination
Furthermore, good sons!
How do Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who cultivate the subtle canon of the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a-sÅ«tra perfect and accomplish the seventh merit?
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who cultivate the subtle canon of the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a-sÅ«tra think like this:
'What dharma can serve as a proximate cause for the great parinirvÄá¹‡a?'
The bodhisattvas immediately know that there are four kinds of dharmas that serve as proximate causes for the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
If it is said:
'Diligent cultivation of all ascetic practices is a proximate cause for the great parinirvÄá¹‡a,'
this is not so.
Why is it so?
If one attains nirvÄá¹‡a apart from the four dharmas, there is no such possibility.
What are the four?
First, to be close to good friends; second, to listen to the Dharma single-mindedly; third, to contemplate with focused attention; fourth, to practice in accordance with the Dharma.
Good man!

It is like a person who encounters various illnesses - hot, cold, phlegm, intermittent fever, various evil spirits and poisons - going to a good doctor, and the good doctor immediately prescribes medicine according to the illness.
This person sincerely accepts the doctor's instructions, mixes the medicine according to the instructions, and takes it according to the method.
After taking it, the illness is cured and the body gains peace and joy.
The person with an illness is likened to the bodhisattvas;
The good doctor is likened to the good and virtuous friends;ğŸ”½The prescriptions of the good doctor are likened to the Vaipulya sutras;
Sincerely accepting the doctor's instructions is likened to contemplating the meaning of the Vaipulya sutras;
Mixing the medicine according to the instructions is likened to practicing the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment according to the Dharma;
The cure of the illness is likened to the extinction of afflictions;
Attaining peace and happiness is a metaphor for attaining nirvÄá¹‡a, which is characterized by permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Good sons!
It is like a king who wishes to rule according to the Dharma, bringing peace and happiness to the people, consulting with wise ministers about the methods.
The ministers then explain the old laws of the former kings.

Having heard them, the king sincerely believes and practices them, ruling the country according to the Dharma, without any enemies. Therefore, he brings peace and happiness to the people, free from worries.
Good sons!
The king is a metaphor for the bodhisattvas;
The wise ministers are a metaphor for the good and wise friends;
The methods of governance explained by the wise ministers for the king are a metaphor for the twelve divisions of the scriptures;

Having heard them, the king sincerely believes and practices them, which is a metaphor for the bodhisattvas focusing their thoughts and contemplating the profound meanings in the twelve divisions of the scriptures;

Governing the country according to the Dharma is analogous to bodhisattvas practicing according to the Dharma - namely, the six perfections. Because they are able to cultivate the six perfections, they have no enemies, analogous to bodhisattvas already free from the afflictions and evil thieves;
Attaining peace and happiness is analogous to bodhisattvas attaining great nirvÄá¹‡a, permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Good man!
It is like a person who encounters a severe leprosy illness. A good friend tells them:
'If you can go to the side of Mount Sumeru, your illness can be cured.
Why is this?
There is a fine medicine there, tasting like nectar. If you can take it, the illness will be cured without fail.'
The person, with a sincere mind believing in this matter, then goes to the mountain, collects and takes the nectar, and their illness is cured, and they attain physical peace and happiness.
The severe leprosy illness is analogous to ordinary beings;
The good friend is analogous to the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas;
To sincerely believe and accept is like the four immeasurables;
Mount Sumeru is a metaphor for the Eightfold Noble Path;
The taste of nectar is a metaphor for buddha-nature;
The cure of leprosy is a metaphor for the extinction of afflictions;
Obtaining peace and happiness is a metaphor for attaining nirvÄá¹‡a, permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Good man!
It is like a person who raises disciples who are intelligent and greatly wise. This person always teaches them day and night without being lazy.
The bodhisattvas are also like this. They always teach and transform all beings, whether they have faith or not, without being weary.
Good man!
Good and virtuous friends refer to buddhas, bodhisattvas, pratyekabuddhas, Å›rÄvakas, and those among people who have faith in the MahÄyÄna.
Why are they called good and virtuous friends?
Good and virtuous friends are able to teach beings to stay far away from the ten evil deeds and to cultivate the ten good deeds.
For this reason, they are called good and virtuous friends.
Furthermore, a good and virtuous friend speaks in accordance with the Dharma and practices in accordance with what is said.
What is meant by speaking in accordance with the Dharma and practicing in accordance with what is said?
Not killing oneself, teaching others not to kill, up to practicing right view oneself and teaching others right view.
If one can be like this, then one can be called a true good and virtuous friend.
Cultivating enlightenment oneself, and also being able to teach others to cultivate enlightenment.
For this reason, it is called a good and virtuous friend.
Cultivating faith, precepts, giving, learning, and wisdom oneself, and also being able to teach others faith, precepts, giving, learning, and wisdom.
For this reason, it is also called a good and virtuous friend.
A good and virtuous friend has good dharmas.
What are the good dharmas?
Not seeking one's own happiness in what one does, but always seeking happiness for sentient beings;
Seeing others' faults, they do not speak of their shortcomings, but always proclaim pure and good things with their mouths.
For this reason, they are called good and virtuous friends.
Good sons!
Just as the moon in the sky, from the first day to the fifteenth day, gradually increases in brightness,
so too are good and virtuous friends, causing students to gradually distance themselves from bad dharmas and increase good dharmas.
Good sons!

If there are those who draw near to good and virtuous friends, those who have not previously had precepts, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and insight of liberation will immediately have them, and those who are not yet complete will be able to increase them.
Why is this?
It is because they draw near to good and virtuous friends.
Because of this intimacy, they will also be able to understand the profound meanings of the twelve divisions of the scriptures.
If one is able to listen to the profound meanings of the twelve divisions of the scriptures, it is called listening to the Dharma.

Listening to the Dharma is the Mahayana Vaipulya scriptures. Listening to the Vaipulya sutras is called truly listening to the Dharma. Truly listening to the Dharma is listening to and accepting the Sutra of Great Nirvana.
In the Great Nirvana Sutra, one hears of the Buddha-nature and that the Tathagata ultimately does not enter parinirvana. Therefore, it is called listening to the Dharma with a focused mind.
Listening to the Dharma with a focused mind is called the Eightfold Noble Path. Because the Eightfold Noble Path can eliminate greed, anger, and delusion, it is called listening to the Dharma.
Those who listen to the Dharma are called the Eleven Kinds of Emptiness. With these kinds of emptiness, one does not form conceptual characteristics towards all dharmas.

Those who listen to the Dharma are called those who first give rise to the mind of enlightenment up to the mind of ultimate supreme perfect enlightenment. Because of the initial mind, one attains the great nirvana, not because of hearing it, but because of cultivation and practice that one attains the great nirvana.
Good man!
It is like a sick person who, although he hears the doctor's instructions and the names of the medicines, cannot be cured of his illness. He must take the medicine in order to be cured.

Although one listens to the twelve profound principles of dependent origination, one cannot eliminate all afflictions. One must concentrate the mind and contemplate well in order to be able to eliminate them. This is called the third, the contemplation of concentration.
What is the meaning of the contemplation of concentration?
It refers to the three samÄdhis:
The samÄdhi of emptiness, the samÄdhi of signlessness, and the samÄdhi of wishlessness.
Emptiness means not seeing any reality in the twenty-five forms of existence;
Wishlessness means not making any vows or aspirations regarding the twenty-five forms of existence;
Signlessness means being free from the ten signs, namely, the signs of form, sound, smell, taste, touch, birth, abiding, cessation, male, and female.
Cultivating these three samÄdhis is called the bodhisattva's contemplation of concentration.
What is meant by practicing in accordance with the Dharma?

Practicing in accordance with the Dharma is practicing the perfection of giving, up to the perfection of wisdom, knowing the true characteristics of the aggregates, sense bases, and elements, and also knowing that the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and buddhas all attain parinirvÄá¹‡a through the same path.

The Dharma is permanence, bliss, self, and purity; it does not arise, does not age, does not get sick, does not die, is not hungry, is not thirsty, is not suffering, is not distressed, does not regress, and does not sink.
Good man!
Those who understand the profound meaning of the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra know that the buddhas will never finally enter nirvÄá¹‡a.
Good man!
The foremost true good and virtuous friend is the bodhisattvas and the buddhas, the world-honored ones.
Why is it so?
Because they always skillfully tame in three ways.
What are the three?
First, ultimately gentle speech; second, ultimately scolding; third, gentle speech and scolding.
For this reason, bodhisattvas and buddhas are true good and wise advisors.
Moreover, good man!
Buddhas and bodhisattvas are great physicians, thus called good and wise advisors.
Why is it so?
They know the illness and the medicine, and prescribe the medicine according to the illness, thus likened to a good doctor.
Skilled in the eight kinds of medical techniques, they first observe the signs of the illness.
There are three kinds of signs.
What are the three?
They are wind, heat, and water.ğŸ”½For those with wind illnesses, they prescribe ghee and oil;
for those with heat illnesses, they prescribe rock candy;
for those with water illnesses, they prescribe ginger soup.
By knowing the root of the illness and prescribing the medicine, the illness is cured, thus called a good doctor.
Buddhas and bodhisattvas are also like this. They know that ordinary beings have three kinds of illnesses:
First, greed and desire, second, anger and hatred, third, ignorance and delusion.
For those with the illness of greed and desire, teach them to contemplate the appearance of bones;
For those with the illness of anger and hatred, contemplate the appearance of compassion;
For those with the illness of ignorance and delusion, contemplate the appearance of the twelve links of dependent origination.
For this reason, buddhas and bodhisattvas are called good and virtuous friends.
Good man!
It is like a boatman who is called a great boatman because he is good at ferrying people across.
Buddhas and bodhisattvas are also like this, delivering sentient beings across the great ocean of birth and death.
For this reason, they are called good and virtuous friends.
Furthermore, good man!
Because of buddhas and bodhisattvas, sentient beings are able to cultivate and attain the roots of good dharmas.
Good man!
It is like the snow mountains, which are the source of various wonderful and superior medicines.
Buddhas and bodhisattvas are also like this, being the source of all the roots of goodness.
For this reason, they are called good and virtuous friends.
Good sons!

In the Himalayas there is a supreme fragrant medicine called sahe. If someone sees it, they will attain immeasurable longevity and be free from illness and suffering. Even the four poisons cannot harm them;
if someone touches it, their lifespan will be extended to 120 years;
if someone thinks of it, they will attain the wisdom of past lives.
Why is this?
Because of the power of the medicine.
The buddhas and bodhisattvas are also like this. If someone sees them, they will immediately be able to eliminate all afflictions, and even the four demons will not be able to disturb them;

if someone touches them, their life cannot be cut short, and they will not be born, die, regress, or sink. As for touching them, if one is by the Buddha's side listening to and receiving the wonderful Dharma, if one thinks of them, one will attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
For this reason, the buddhas and bodhisattvas are called good and virtuous friends.
Good man!
Like in the Fragrant Mountains there is the Anavatapta Pond, from which there are four great rivers, namely the Ganges, the Indus, the Sita, and the Vakshu.
Sentient beings in the world always say:
'If there are those with offenses, bathing in these four rivers can eliminate all offenses.'
You should know that these words are false and not true.
Apart from this, what is true?
The Buddhas and Bodhisattvas are true.
Why is it so?
If a person draws near, they can eliminate all offenses.
For this reason, it is called a good and virtuous friend.
Furthermore, good man!

It is like the great earth, with all the medicinal herbs, trees, forests, hundreds of grains, sugarcane, flowers and fruits, when struck by the hot weather and drought, about to wither and die. The dragons Nanda and Upananda, out of compassion for sentient beings, emerge from the great ocean and pour down sweet rain, causing all the forests, hundreds of grains, grasses and trees to be nourished and grow again.

All sentient beings are also like this. The roots of goodness they possess are about to be exhausted. The Buddhas and Bodhisattvas give rise to great compassion and pour down the rain of sweet dew from the ocean of wisdom, causing sentient beings to be replete and regain the Dharma of the ten wholesome deeds.
For this reason, the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas are called good and virtuous friends.
Good man!

It is like a good doctor skilled in the eight branches of medicine, who sees all sick people without regard to their social class, appearance, wealth or possessions, and treats them all. For this reason, he is called a great doctor in the world.

The buddhas and bodhisattvas are also like this. Seeing that sentient beings have the illness of afflictions, they do not consider their family background, whether they are handsome or ugly, or their wealth and treasures. With a compassionate mind, they expound the Dharma for them all.
When sentient beings hear it, the illness of afflictions is cured.
For this reason, the buddhas and bodhisattvas are called good and virtuous friends.
By relying on good and virtuous friends, one can then approach great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
How do bodhisattvas, by the causal conditions of listening to the Dharma, get close to great parinirvÄá¹‡a?

Because all sentient beings listen to the Dharma, they are endowed with the faculty of faith. Because they obtain the faculty of faith, they enjoy practicing giving, morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom, and attain the fruit of stream-entry up to the fruit of buddhahood.
Therefore, you should know that:
Obtaining all wholesome dharmas is the power of the causal conditions of listening to the Dharma.
Good sons!
It is like an elder who has only one son. He sends him to another country to trade for necessities. He shows him the routes, the passable and impassable places, and admonishes him:
'If you encounter a prostitute, do not be intimate with her.
If you are intimate with her, you will lose your body, life, and wealth.
Do not associate with evil people either.'
The son respectfully followed his father's instructions, and his body and mind were at ease, and he obtained much treasure.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas expound the Dharma for sentient beings in the same way. They show sentient beings and the four groups of Buddhist followers the passable and impassable paths.
Because these sentient beings and the four groups have heard the Dharma, they have abandoned all evil and are endowed with good dharmas.
For this reason, the causes and conditions of listening to the Dharma can lead one to the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Good man!
It is like a clear mirror, which reflects a person's face without fail.

For this reason, the causes and conditions of listening to the Dharma lead to the attainment of great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Good son!
It is like a merchant who wants to reach a treasure island but does not know the road.
Someone shows him the way, and the merchant follows the instructions to reach the treasure island and obtains countless precious treasures.
All sentient beings are also like this. They want to reach a good place and gather the treasures of the Way, but they do not know the characteristics of the road's openness and obstruction.
The bodhisattvas show them the way, and the sentient beings follow and reach a good place, obtaining the treasure of the unsurpassed great nirvÄá¹‡a.
For this reason, the causes and conditions of listening to the Dharma lead to the attainment of great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Good son!
It is like a drunken elephant, wild, violent, and evil, wanting to kill many people.
A skilled elephant trainer uses a large iron hook to pierce the top of the elephant's head, and it immediately becomes obedient, with all evil intentions completely gone.
All sentient beings are also like this. Because they are intoxicated by greed, anger, and delusion, they wish to create much evil.
The bodhisattvas use the hook of hearing the Dharma to pierce them and make them abide, so that they can no longer give rise to the intention to create evil.
For this reason, the causes and conditions of listening to the Dharma can bring one close to the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.

Therefore, I have said in various sÅ«tras that my disciples who single-mindedly listen to and accept the twelve divisions of the canon will be free from the five hindrances and cultivate the seven factors of awakening.

Why is it so?

The elder Sudatta was seriously ill and his heart was greatly distressed. He heard ÅšÄriputra say that a stream-enterer has four merits and ten kinds of comfort and consolation. Having heard this, his fear was immediately dispelled.

Why is it so?
Because it opens the Dharma eye.
There are three kinds of people in the world:
First, those without eyes; second, those with one eye; third, those with two eyes.
Those without eyes never hear the Dharma;
Those with one eye, although they temporarily hear the Dharma, their minds are not settled;
Those with two eyes single-mindedly listen and accept, and practice as they hear.
Because of listening to the Dharma, one knows that there are such three kinds of people in the world.
For this reason, the cause and condition of listening to the Dharma is to be able to approach great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Good man!
As I was in the city of KuÅ›inagara, at that time ÅšÄriputra's body encountered illness and suffering.
I then instructed the bhiká¹£u Ä€nanda to extensively expound the Dharma for them.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra, having heard this, told his four disciples:
You should carry my bed to where the Buddha is. I wish to listen to the Dharma.
The four disciples then carried him as ordered.
Having heard the Dharma, by the power of hearing the Dharma, his suffering was cured and his body became peaceful and comfortable.
For this reason, the cause and condition of listening to the Dharma leads to being close to the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
How does a bodhisattva attain being close to the great parinirvÄá¹‡a by contemplating causes and conditions?
Because of this contemplation, the mind attains liberation.
Why is it so?
All sentient beings are always bound by the five desires, but because of contemplation, they all attain liberation.
For this reason, the cause and condition of contemplation leads to being close to the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Moreover, good man!
All sentient beings are always inverted by the four dharmas of permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
By means of contemplation, one can see that all dharmas are impermanent, without bliss, without self, and impure.
Having seen this, the four inversions are then eliminated.
For this reason, contemplating the causes and conditions can bring one close to the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Moreover, good man!
All dharmas have four characteristics.
What are the four?
First, the characteristic of birth; second, the characteristic of aging; third, the characteristic of sickness; fourth, the characteristic of cessation.
These four characteristics can cause all ordinary sentient beings up to srotÄpannas to experience great suffering.
If one can focus the mind and contemplate well, then even encountering these four, one will not give rise to various sufferings.
For this reason, contemplating the causes and conditions can bring one close to the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Moreover, good man!
All wholesome dharmas are not attained without this contemplation.
Why is it so?

Even if someone single-mindedly listens to the Dharma for immeasurable and limitless asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, if they do not contemplate, they will ultimately not be able to attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
For this reason, the cause and condition of contemplation can then approach great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Moreover, good man!

If there are sentient beings who have faith in the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹ƒgha without change and give rise to reverence, one should know that this is all due to the power of the cause and condition of focused contemplation, and thus they can eliminate all afflictions.
For this reason, the cause and condition of contemplation can then approach great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
What is it for the bodhisattvas to practice in accordance with the Dharma?
Good man!
Cutting off unwholesome dharmas and cultivating wholesome dharmas is called the bodhisattvas' practice in accordance with the Dharma.
Furthermore, what is it to practice in accordance with the Dharma?
Seeing all dharmas as empty and nonexistent, impermanent, without joy, without self, and impure.
Because of this view, they would rather give up their lives than violate the precepts. This is called the bodhisattvas' practice in accordance with the Dharma.
Furthermore, what is practice in accordance with the Dharma?
There are two kinds of practice:
1. Real, and 2. Unreal.
The unreal is not knowing the true characteristics of nirvana, buddha-nature, the Tathagata, the Dharma, the Sangha, emptiness, and so forth. This is called unreal.
What is real?
Being able to know the true characteristics of nirvana, buddha-nature, the Tathagata, the Dharma, the Sangha, emptiness, and so forth. This is called real.
What is meant by knowing the characteristics of nirvana?
There are eight aspects to the characteristics of nirvana.
What are the eight?

First, it is extinguished; second, it is of good nature; third, it is real; fourth, it is true; fifth, it is permanent; sixth, it is blissful; seventh, it is self; and eighth, it is pure. This is called nirvÄá¹‡a.
There are also eight other aspects.
What are the eight?
First, liberation; second, good nature; third, unreal; fourth, untrue; fifth, impermanent; sixth, not blissful; seventh, not self; and eighth, not pure.
There are also six characteristics:
First, liberation; second, good nature; third, unreal; fourth, untrue; fifth, peaceful and blissful; and sixth, pure.
If there are sentient beings who rely on the worldly path to eliminate afflictions, such nirvÄá¹‡a has eight aspects, and liberation is unreal.
Why is this?ğŸ”½Because it is not permanent.
Because it is impermanent, it is not real;
Because it is not real, it is not true.
Although afflictions are severed, they arise again, so it is impermanent, non-self, suffering, and impure.
These are called the eight aspects of liberation in nirvana.
What are the six characteristics?
ÅšrÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas are called liberated because they have severed afflictions;
but because they have not yet attained anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, they are called unreal;
because they are unreal, they are called not true;
because in the future they will attain anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, they are called impermanent;
because they have attained the eight uncontaminated holy paths, they are called pure and blissful.
Good son!
If one knows in this way, it is called knowing nirvana, not the true nature of the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹ƒgha, or emptiness.
What is meant by bodhisattvas knowing the Buddha-nature?
The Buddha-nature has six aspects.
What are the six?
First, permanence, second, purity, third, reality, fourth, goodness, fifth, should be seen, sixth, truth.
There are also seven things:
The first is testability, the other six are the same as above.
This is called the bodhisattva knowing the buddha-nature.
How does the bodhisattva know the characteristics of the TathÄgata?

The TathÄgata is the characteristic of enlightenment, the characteristic of goodness, permanence, bliss, self, purity, liberation, reality, the path that can be shown, this is called the bodhisattva knowing the characteristics of the TathÄgata.
How does the bodhisattva know the characteristics of the Dharma?

The Dharma refers to what is good or not good, permanent or impermanent, blissful or not blissful, self or no self, pure or impure, known or unknown, understood or misunderstood, true or untrue, cultivated or not cultivated, a teacher or not a teacher, real or unreal, this is called the bodhisattva knowing the characteristics of the Dharma.
How do bodhisattvas know the characteristics of the Saá¹…gha?
The Saá¹…gha is characterized by permanence, bliss, self, and purity, is characterized by being the disciples of the Buddha, is visible, good, true, and not real.
Why is this?
Because all Å›rÄvakas will attain buddhahood.
Why is it called true?
Because it realizes the nature of dharmas.
This is called the bodhisattvas' knowledge of the characteristics of the Saá¹…gha.
How do bodhisattvas know the characteristics of reality?

The characteristics of reality are neither permanent nor impermanent, neither blissful nor not blissful, neither a self nor not a self, neither pure nor impure, neither good nor not good, neither existent nor nonexistent, neither nirvÄá¹‡a nor not nirvÄá¹‡a, neither liberation nor not liberation, neither knowledge nor not knowledge, neither cut off nor not cut off, neither realized nor not realized, neither cultivated nor not cultivated, neither seen nor not seen. This is called the characteristics of reality, which is neither nirvÄá¹‡a, buddha-nature, tathÄgata, Dharma, Saá¹…gha, nor space.

This is called the bodhisattva's knowledge of the distinctions in the characteristics of nirvana, buddha-nature, the TathÄgata, the Dharma, the Saá¹ƒgha, reality, and space, due to cultivating the great nirvana in this way.
Good son!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivating the subtle sÅ«tra of the great nirvana do not see space.
Why is this?
Although buddhas and bodhisattvas have the five eyes, they do not see it. Only the eye of wisdom can see it.
What the eye of wisdom sees cannot be seen, and therefore it is called seeing.
If seeing nothing is called space, then such space is called real.
Because it is real, it is called permanently nonexistent.
Because it is permanently nonexistent, it has no bliss, self, or purity.
Good son!
Space is called the absence of dharmas, and the absence of dharmas is called space.
It is like the world, where the absence of things is called space.
The nature of space is also like this, being called space because of its non-existence.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Good man!
The nature of sentient beings and the nature of space are both without any real nature.
Why is this?
It is like when a person says:
'After eliminating existent things, then space is made.'
But space is actually uncreatable.
Why is this?
Because it is nonexistent.
Since it is nonexistent, one should know that there is no space.
If the nature of space can be created, then it would be called impermanent;
if it is impermanent, it cannot be called space.
Good man!
It is like worldly people saying:
'Space is formless, unobstructed, permanent, and unchanging.'
Therefore, the world calls the dharma of space the fifth great element.
Good man!
But this nature of space is actually nonexistent.
Because of light, it is called space, but there is actually no space.
It is just like the truth of the world, which actually has no nature, but for the sake of sentient beings, it is said that there is the truth of the world.
Good man!
The essence of nirvana is also like this, without any abode. It is simply the place where the buddhas sever afflictions, and is therefore called nirvana.
Nirvana is precisely permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Although nirvana is bliss, it is not the bliss of sensation, but rather the supreme, wondrous bliss of quiescent extinction.
The buddhas and tathÄgatas have two kinds of bliss:
First, the bliss of quiescent extinction; second, the bliss of awakened cognition.
The essence of reality has three kinds of bliss:
First, the bliss of sensation; second, the bliss of quiescent extinction; third, the bliss of awakened cognition.
Buddha-nature is one kind of bliss. Because it is to be seen, when attaining anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, it is called the bliss of bodhi.
At that time, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva Supreme Virtuous King of Universal Illumination addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If the place where afflictions are severed is nirvana, this is not so.
Why is it so?
In the past, when the TathÄgata first attained Buddhahood, he went to the banks of the NairaÃ±janÄ River.
At that time, MÄra, the evil one, together with his retinue, came to where the Buddha was and said these words:
World-Honored One!
